Do you suffer from painful periods? \nTake this questionnaire to find out your risk for endometriosis.

The PainCare m-Health solution was developed with the goal of providing comprehensive resources and assistance to women who are struggling with endometriosis. It aims to assist individuals by giving them access to customized symptom tracking, educational materials, and a supportive community. The main goal is to provide women with endometriosis with a user-friendly and accessible tool for pain-management, information, and emotional support in order to improve their overall wellness and quality of life. This includes women who suspect they may have the condition. With PainCare, women can take control of their condition and move towards a happier and healthier life.
Are you sure you want to delete your account?
What are the symptoms of Endometriosis?
What can raise my chances of suffering from Endometriosis?
How can I reduce my chances of getting Endometriosis?
Why is it important to find out if I have Endometriosis?

The most common symptom of Endometriosis is pelvic pain. The pain often occurs with menstruation, during ovulation, and/or in connection with sexual intercourse. However, a woman with Endometriosis may also experience pain at other times during her monthly cycle. Another symptom is infertility. Some women with Endometriosis also experience severe fatigue.
Endometriosis is a condition where tissue similar to the lining of the uterus is also found elsewhere in the body, mainly in the abdominal cavity.

You are more likely to get Endometriosis if you have: 
•Never had children. 
•Menstrual periods that last more than seven days. 
•Short menstrual cycles (27 days or less). 
•A family member (mother, aunt, sister) with Endometriosis.
•A health problem that prevents normal passage of menstrual blood flow. 
•Damage to the cells in the pelvis from an infection.

There is no cure for Endometriosis, but there are many treatments for the pain and infertility it causes. Talk with your doctor about what option is best for you. The treatment you choose will depend on your symptoms, age, and plans for getting pregnant.
Pain Medication -— For some women with mild symptoms, doctors may suggest taking over-the-counter medicines for pain.
Hormone Treatment — When pain medicine is not enough, doctors often recommend hormone medicines to treat Endometriosis. Only women who do not wish to become pregnant, can use these drugs.
 Surgery — Surgery is usually the best choice for women with severe Endometriosis with many growths, a great deal of pain, or fertility problems.

Keep lower estrogen levels in your body. Try: 
•Exercising regularly. 
•Keeping a low amount of body fat. 
•Avoiding large amounts of alcohol and drinks with caffeine

Growths of Endometriosis are benign (not cancerous), but they still can cause many problems. Tissue and blood that is shed into the body can cause inflammation, scar tissue, and pain. As endometrial tissue grows, it can cover or grow into the ovaries and block the fallopian tubes. Trapped blood in the ovaries can form cysts as well as cause inflammation scarring (adhesions) that sometimes bind organs together. This scar tissue may cause pelvic pain and make it difficult for women to get pregnant. The growths can also cause problems in the intestines and bladder.

Studies show that women with Endometriosis skip school, work, and social events. This health problem can strain relationships with your partner, friends, children, and co-workers. Plus, Endometriosis can make it difficult for a woman to get pregnant. When Endometriosis causes fertility problems, surgery can boost the chances of getting pregnant.
When do you start your period ?
Do you have a familly history of endometriosis ?
Do you have trouble getting pregnant ?
Body mass index : calculate your BMI
What is your abdominal/pelvic pain intensity ?
When do you experience abdominal or pelvic pain ?
What is your menstrual cycle pattern ?
Have you ever been victim of physical abuse or sexual abuse ?
A condition where the uterus is enlarged.
A condition where the uterine lining sheds more frequently.
A condition where the uterine lining grows outside the uterus.
A condition where the uterus is tilted backward.
A condition where the uterine lining grows outside the uterus.

Endometriosis is characterized by the abnormal growth of tissue resembling the uterine lining outside the uterus. This tissue can attach to various pelvic organs, causing pain, inflammation, and potentially leading to the formation of cysts and adhesions.
What are some common symptoms of endometriosis?

Individuals with endometriosis often experience a combination of symptoms, including pelvic pain, heavy menstrual bleeding, and painful intercourse. The presence of these symptoms can vary based on the extent and location of the abnormal tissue growth.
What is the main cause of endometriosis?

Although hormonal imbalances, genetic predisposition, and inflammation are theorized contributors, the exact root cause of endometriosis remains uncertain. Researchers continue to investigate the complex interplay of factors that may trigger its development.

Laparoscopy, a minimally invasive surgical procedure, is the preferred method for diagnosing endometriosis. It allows direct visualization of pelvic organs, identification of abnormal tissue growth, and often enables simultaneous treatment during the procedure.
What is the primary treatment for endometriosis?

Hormonal therapy, such as birth control pills or GnRH agonists, is commonly chosen as the primary treatment for endometriosis. These therapies aim to regulate hormone levels and create an environment less conducive to the growth of endometrial tissue outside the uterus.
No, it does not impact fertility.
It depends on the severity of the condition.

Endometriosis can lead to fertility challenges due to its potential to cause structural damage, adhesions, and inflammation in the pelvic region. These factors can hinder the normal function of reproductive organs and decrease the chances of successful conception.
What are some risk factors for developing endometriosis?

Early menarche, late menopause, and a family history of endometriosis are established risk factors. These factors influence hormonal exposure and genetic susceptibility, increasing the likelihood of developing the condition.
Is there a cure for endometriosis?
Yes, it can be completely cured.
No, there is no known cure.
Surgery can provide a permanent cure.
Endometriosis resolves on its own over time.
No, there is no known cure.

Despite various treatment approaches, a definitive cure for endometriosis is currently unavailable. While symptoms can be managed and quality of life improved, the underlying condition itself persists.
The outer layer of the uterus.
The inner lining of the uterus.
The inner lining of the uterus.
The endometrium is the innermost layer of the uterus that thickens and sheds cyclically in response to hormonal changes. This process is central to the menstrual cycle and plays a role in pregnancy.
Can endometriosis be managed through lifestyle changes?
Yes, diet and exercise can help alleviate symptoms.
No, lifestyle changes have no impact on endometriosis.
Yes, diet and exercise can help alleviate symptoms.

While medical interventions are crucial, adopting a healthy lifestyle including a balanced diet and regular exercise can contribute positively. These practices can potentially reduce inflammation, manage pain, and enhance overall well-being for individuals living with endometriosis.
The ability to conceive a child.
The presence of a regular menstrual cycle.
The absence of reproductive health issues.
The ability to carry a pregnancy to term.
The ability to conceive a child.

Fertility refers to the biological capability of an individual to conceive and bear children. It encompasses the capacity of the reproductive system to facilitate the union of sperm and egg, leading to pregnancy.
What is the most effective form of contraception?

Intrauterine devices (IUDs) are among the most effective forms of contraception. They have a very low failure rate due to their direct placement within the uterus, preventing fertilization and implantation.
How do hormonal contraceptives prevent pregnancy?

Hormonal contraceptives, such as birth control pills, patches, and injections, work primarily by suppressing ovulation. This prevents the release of an egg from the ovaries, making fertilization impossible.
A method used after unprotected sex to prevent pregnancy.
A method used after unprotected sex to prevent pregnancy.

Emergency contraception refers to methods used after unprotected sexual intercourse or contraceptive failure to prevent pregnancy. It includes methods like morning-after pills and copper IUD insertion within a specific timeframe.
What is the failure rate of typical use for most contraceptives?

The failure rate of most contraceptives with typical use falls within the range of 5-10%. This includes variations due to inconsistent use, incorrect application, or external factors that may reduce their effectiveness.
Tracking menstrual cycles to determine fertility.
Tracking menstrual cycles to determine fertility.

Natural family planning involves tracking menstrual cycles and fertility signs to identify the fertile window. Couples can then choose to abstain from intercourse during this period to avoid pregnancy without using artificial contraceptives.
What is the purpose of sterilization as a contraceptive method?

Sterilization involves the surgical blocking or sealing of the fallopian tubes (tubal ligation in females) to prevent the passage of eggs and sperm. This permanent method ensures that fertilization cannot occur.
What is the recommended age to start using contraception?
When planning to have a child.

The onset of menstruation, known as menarche, signifies the potential for fertility. It is recommended to start using contraception around this time to prevent unintended pregnancies as individuals become capable of reproductive functions.
Can contraceptives protect against sexually transmitted infections (STIs)?
Yes, all contraceptives provide protection against STIs.
No, contraceptives do not protect against STIs.
Only barrier methods of contraception provide protection against STIs.
Contraceptives can sometimes protect against STIs.
No, contraceptives do not protect against STIs.

Most contraceptives are designed solely to prevent pregnancy and do not provide protection against sexually transmitted infections (STIs). Barrier methods, like condoms, are the exception, offering dual protection by preventing both pregnancy and STI transmission.
What is the purpose of a contraceptive implant?

Contraceptive implants are small devices inserted under the skin that release hormones to prevent pregnancy. They offer a highly effective, long-term contraceptive solution without the need for daily administration, providing continuous protection over several years.
Overall well-being of the reproductive system.
Physical and emotional well-being in romantic relationships.

Intimate health encompasses various aspects, including the well-being of the reproductive system, physical and emotional health within romantic relationships, and the maintenance of healthy intimate relationships overall.
What are some common intimate health concerns in women?
Common intimate health concerns in women include vaginal infections, urinary tract infections, and sexually transmitted infections. These can impact both physical and emotional well-being.
What are some recommended practices for maintaining intimate health?
Maintaining intimate health involves practicing safe sex, maintaining good hygiene practices, and seeking regular healthcare check-ups. These practices contribute to overall well-being.
What are some signs of a vaginal infection?
Signs of a vaginal infection can include abnormal discharge, itching or irritation, and a foul odor. These symptoms may indicate an imbalance in vaginal health.
What are some ways to prevent urinary tract infections (UTIs)?
Urinate before and after sexual activity.
Wipe from front to back after using the restroom.
Preventing UTIs involves staying hydrated, urinating before and after sexual activity, and maintaining proper hygiene practices. These measures can help reduce the risk of infection.
Why is it important to communicate with your partner about intimate health?
To maintain open and honest communication.
To discuss any concerns or issues.
To ensure both partners are informed and involved.

Open communication about intimate health is vital to maintain trust and understanding in a relationship. Discussing concerns and involving both partners ensures a supportive and informed approach to intimate well-being.
What are some recommended products for maintaining intimate health?
Gentle cleansers or washes specifically designed for intimate use.

Recommended products for maintaining intimate health include gentle cleansers or washes designed for intimate use, unscented and hypoallergenic products, as well as breathable cotton underwear that promotes air circulation.
What should you do if you experience persistent discomfort or pain during intercourse?
Seek medical advice from a healthcare provider.
Communicate with your partner about the issue.
Experiment with different positions or lubricants.

Experiencing persistent discomfort or pain during intercourse should prompt seeking medical advice from a healthcare provider. Additionally, open communication with your partner and trying different approaches can contribute to finding solutions to the issue.
What are some ways to promote emotional intimacy in a relationship?

Promoting emotional intimacy involves open and honest communication, active listening to each other\'s feelings, and demonstrating empathy and understanding. These practices strengthen the emotional connection within a relationship.
Why is it important to prioritize self-care in intimate health?
To maintain overall well-being and happiness.
To enhance self-confidence and body image.
To reduce stress and promote relaxation.

Prioritizing self-care in intimate health contributes to overall well-being, enhances self-confidence and positive body image, and helps in reducing stress and promoting relaxation. These factors collectively support a healthier and more fulfilling intimate life.
The process of shedding the uterine lining.
The release of an unfertilized egg from the ovaries.
The entire reproductive cycle of a woman.
The production of hormones by the endocrine system.
The entire reproductive cycle of a woman.

The menstrual cycle encompasses various hormonal and physiological changes that occur in a woman\'s body, preparing for potential pregnancy and the shedding of the uterine lining if pregnancy doesn\'t occur.
What is the average duration of a menstrual cycle?
The average menstrual cycle typically lasts around 28 days, although variations in cycle length are common among individuals.
Which hormone is responsible for stimulating the growth and development of the uterine lining?
Estrogen plays a crucial role in stimulating the growth and development of the uterine lining during the first half of the menstrual cycle.
When does ovulation typically occur in a menstrual cycle?
At the beginning of the cycle.
In the middle of the cycle.
At the end of the cycle.
In the middle of the cycle.
Ovulation generally occurs in the middle of the menstrual cycle, around day 14, and marks the release of an egg from the ovary, ready for potential fertilization.
What is the purpose of the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle?
To prepare the uterus for pregnancy.
To produce hormones that regulate the cycle.
To prepare the uterus for pregnancy.

The luteal phase follows ovulation and involves the development of the uterine lining to create a suitable environment for a potential pregnancy. If fertilization doesn\'t occur, the uterine lining is eventually shed.
Amenorrhea refers to the absence of menstrual periods, which can be caused by factors such as pregnancy, certain medical conditions, or changes in hormonal balance.
What is the role of the corpus luteum in the menstrual cycle?
To release the egg during ovulation.
The corpus luteum, formed from the follicle that released the egg during ovulation, plays a key role in producing progesterone, which maintains the uterine lining and supports a potential pregnancy.
What happens if fertilization and implantation do not occur?
The uterine lining is shed during menstruation.
The uterus becomes dormant until the next cycle.
The uterine lining is shed during menstruation.
If fertilization and implantation do not occur, the corpus luteum regresses, causing a drop in progesterone levels. This leads to the shedding of the uterine lining, resulting in menstruation.
What are some common symptoms experienced during the menstrual cycle?
Many individuals experience various symptoms during their menstrual cycle, including breast tenderness, mood swings, and cramps, due to hormonal fluctuations and changes in the uterine lining.

Menorrhagia refers to abnormally heavy or prolonged menstrual bleeding that can impact an individual\'s quality of life and may be caused by factors such as hormonal imbalances or certain medical conditions.
